I think this song is far more personal to James than being about soldiers off to war but everyone is entitled to their interpretation. It has a great dream like quality, rich in symbolism. Ultimately it is about James' feelings toward his mother. Remember that he starts the song addressing his mother. 

There is a tradition where a lighted candle is lit and left in the window to help travellers find their way back home. In this song it sets a metaphor of the home being the family and the love that holds the family together. That love keeps a person returning to their family, their mother, throughout the journey of life. The travelers represent the author who like all children sets out on the journey of life looking to be cared for. A hero is someone who saves you, protects you and cares for you. This also the role of a mother. The Hero of the Day that he seeks is his mother.

But in this case something is wrong because the window itself is lit on fire suggesting that the person at home is over zealous in their desire for the travellers to return. Their love could actually destroy the home. The idea of being overwhelmed by his mother's love is common in James lyrics, like the Apron strings around his neck in Mama Said or the fury he feels in Dyer's Eve. And just as in Dyer's Eve he feels unprepared to face the world due to being sheltered from it by his mother, James expresses that same fear and anger toward his mother because now that he is on this journey and she is gone he feels vulnerable to the world and worries that he may fall by someone's wicked ways. He wonders if his mother can hear her baby crying, does she know the pain he feels? All he can hear is her sighing. Now that she is dead all that remains is the whispers of her voice in her mind.

As the song progresses you feel that transition from the soothing mellow intro that is like being cradled by his mother's love to that furious anger expressed as the music breaks into the verse about the dreams and the waking screams which is him living through the pain and anger he feels toward a mother he can no longer reconcile with. And then of course the song ends with the repetition of the whole point of the song,  that the world is trying to break him and his need to feel her love again. Always James wants love but is afraid of it because love is control to him.

First, this is a fantastic song because it can mean so many different things to so many different people.  That said, let me give what it means to me.

The first part of the song is a reference to soldiers going off to war and how there thoughts are always on home.  The line "if they should fall by someone's wicked way" is about falling in battle.

The second part is about how so many soldiers continue to fight the war after they come home. "no, I'm not all me" is about how a soldier is forever changed into a different person by war, while "things return to me that still seem real" is a clear reference to PTSD, along with "but now the dreams and waking screams that ever last the night".  

I think the song refers to how a soldier going off to war is "the hero of the day" and then how different it is when they come home.  Even things like "don't want your aid", clearly about how a lot of soldiers try to deal with PTSD themselves instead of seeking help.
Just my 2 cents worth.

Hero of the Day Interpretation: Personal victory is within our reach. Each person in this war is fighting not to win, but to find their honor.  
What if someone fighting, dies in vein? 
The fight is so long and hard, it's easy to become discouraged.  Keepers of these inner flames that thirst for honor, can you acknowledge
the ones who care about you, praying for your safe return from your journey?  Your loved ones want you with them, not your dream of
personal conquest.  Will the enemy break my will?  They haven't relented.  Now this fight seems so vein, remembering the reason I was brought here.
It seems I can relax now, I've remembered the reason for the fight, I shall deservingly sit on the chair of righteousness.  But it's too late, I can't return
back to the way things were because I now live in shame for my vanity.  I've made these mistakes, and now I have to reconcile them without confiding
in the ones I've loved, I have to do it myself(or with God).  I've become a hardened person fighting this war. I've lost the ability to feel.
Please excuse me while I fight my inner demons so that I can save myself from making anyone else a hardened person.  So I seek emotional shelter while
I recover from the trauma of fighting, until I've cleansed myself of the demons(little metal things coming out of the kid's ear, unconsciousness is the 
wall in this case).  The war in my mind continues, I have to fight these demons before it's too late and I can never feel emotion again.  Mama, they try 
and break me while I cleanse myself of these inner demons.  They try, but I will put up my best fight.  Even if I fail, at least I've tried.  The metal
demons are expunged from the kid's mind, the inner battle will eventually die down and peace will be restored.

comment_39: I would say that the war definition would be valid, but one thing that people don't appear to understand is the window part.  A lighted window has been a metaphor for welcoming for a very long time, and it is used in lots of different songs and types of music, like CCR "put a candle in the window", and countless songs talking about leaving a light on for people.  The window burns means that this person, be it a soldier, or just someone who is losing everything and wants to go home, wants to still be welcome back home.  People leave lights on when they know someone is going to be coming, like on halloween, when you're willing to have kids come and trick or treat your house, you put a jackolantern out, a light.  the idea is that if there is a light on, then the people are still thinking of you and expecting you to come back.  The next line, a flame that warms no matter where they've gone, is talking about the comfort given by knowing that light is on.  The candle in the window, although not giving any actual warmth to speak of, still comforts that person, and it doesn't matter how far away that candle is.  and the can you hear your babies' cryin line is asking if they can simpathize with him.  That's the main things that i wanted to point out.  the rest seems to be there pretty good.

comment_69:
This song is about warfare, and the effects it has on its victims, the soldiers. It's about searching for a "hero" among thousands of soldiers who can put an end to the war easily. A "hero" who will fight the war effort and never be recognized for it, because he dies in the war/is paralyzed for life.

"The window burns to light the way back home.. Time so slowly turns""

(symbolizes soldiers' desire to return home, and how it seems like so far in the future. Also time goes by so slowly when at war.) 

"These things return to me that still seem real"
Referring to shell shock (soldiers experiencing flashbacks about the war), which was caused mostly by the Vietnam and gulf wars; 

"Now, deservingly, this easy chair
But the rocking stopped by wheels of despair"
An old man's rocking chair replaced by a wheel chair (wheels of despair), a result of physical paralysis caused by injury in the war.

"Keepers of the flames
Did you hear your names?"
(The countless, nameless soldiers who do not receive recognition for their efforts in the war.)

"But now the dreams and waking screams
That ever last the night"
(Referring to the dreams of returning home, juxtaposed with the waking screams of death at war, and the seemingly everlasting night caused by the war.)

comment_85:
I think that this song is about the anxiety a parent feels when their child strikes out on their own for the first time.

"The window burns to light the way back home
A light that warms no matter where they've gone
They're off to find the hero of the day"

Parents always "leave the light on" for their children when they leave. Their children set off to obsess about people in the media, or to try and impress their new boss or professors at school.

"But what if they should fall by someone's wicked way?"

Parents worry that their children will encounter evil and twisted people that will pervert their child's views.

"Still the window burns
Time so slowly turns
Someone there is sighing
Keepers of the flames
Do you feel your name?
Did you hear your babies crying?"

The parent's sit at home wondering what has become of their child, perhaps the last line means that the kid has gotten into a jam that the parent can't get them out of. All the parent can do is watch and hope they taught their child right.

"Excuse me while I tend to how I feel
These things return to me that still seem real
Now, deservingly, this easy chair
But the rocking stopped by wheels of despair"

Once again, the parent can't do anything but sit in their chair and wonder what has become of their child, not knowing exactly how they feel about the whole situation.

"But now the dreams and waking screams
That ever last the night
So build a wall, behind it crawl
And hide until it's light
So can't you hear your babies crying now?"

Acceptance, the parent realizes that they need to build up their defenses and hope for the best. Everything will turn out all right in the end, even though it looks bleak at the moment.

comment_92:
This song is about war; they way war separates families, leaves the warriors with post traumatic stress and yet still somehow strengthen our familial bonds.

>The window burns to light the way back home
>A light that warms no matter where they've gone

This opening rhyme lets us know that there is a light in the window, more specifically, fire light. Candles placed in the window during the holidays represent love ones off at war. It is a light that burns to light the way back home. 

>They're off to find the hero of the day
>But what if they should fall by someone's wicked way?

In wars fought by American soldiers it is a rule that you never leave a soldier behind, not even if he has died. This is to keep morale up. The enemy could parade a dead body around or even torture a person to gain intel. Often these rescue missions are very very dangerous and involve returning to hostile territory. 


>Still the window burns
>Time so slowly turns
>Someone there is sighing
>Keepers of the flames
>Do you feel your name?
>Did you hear your babies crying?

these two rhyming triplets show us the person or family at home, still tending to the candle in the window, anxiously awaiting the return of their loved ones. The possibility of their death is disconcerting but the family at home is very powerless in this situation. All they can do is sigh.  
The last two lines tie into the practice of torturing POW's; a practice very prevalent during Vietnam. Tortured people commonly call to their loved ones in pain and anguish. 

>Mama, they try and break me
>Still, they try and break me

The purpose of torture is often to "break" a persons will and make them disclose information. 

>Excuse me while I tend to how I feel
>These things return to me that still seem real

Post traumatic stress is a disorder caused by traumatic experiences. Rape victims often suffer from it, and tend to seize up or have dreams and intrusive memories of this trauma. The same goes for people who survived wars. 

>Now, deserving, this easy chair
>But the rocking stopped by wheels of despair

Veterans deserve respect and comfort in their civilian life.

>Don't want your aid
>But the fist I make
>For years can't hold or feel
>No, I'm not all me
>So please excuse me while I tend to how I feel

Veterans can also feel a strong sense of independence due to their experiences and may feel ashamed of receiving help.   The trauma of war often leaves them a different person. 

>But now the dreams and waking screams
>That ever last the night

The nightmares and post traumatic stress is brought up again

>So build the wall, behind it crawl
>And hide until it's light
>So can you hear your babies crying now?

The war veteran can not explain the things that has happened to him; the things he has seen or the manner he has been changed, to some one that has not experienced it first hand. They often retreat and hide their emotions instead of expressing them. 



Overall this song is about the Vietnam war, a POW who was tortured and the strain it has put on his emotional and mental well being as well as the health of his family he returned to.

comment_97:
If anyone has had to deal with PTSD (or anyone with PTSD for that fact) the song kinda brings on a new meaning.  Hetfield is famous for referencing the Vietnam War.  But I'll tell you the song speaks to several of us...we used to listen to Hero of the Day as our pre-mission song.  My reasoning:

(Mama, they try and break me)
(Still, they try and break me) - Both are about combat and the stress of never quite letting go of it.

Excuse me while I tend to how I feel  -  Drinking to remember or forget what has been done in conflict.
These things return to me that still seem real  -  PTSD symptoms...can't let go.
Now, deservingly, this easy chair  -  You've made it home and think things will be better now.
But the rocking stopped by wheels of despair  -  Sorrow for what was done in wartime.

I know this was long, but this song speaks volumes anyone who's been in combat.
